February 19, 1969
Mr. Donald R. Quayle
General Consultant
Corporation for Public Broadcasting
555 Madison Avenue
New York, New York 10022
Dear Don:
It was good to meet with you and Bob Swezey Feb¬
ruary 14. Delighted you could join our brainstorming
lunch and participate in one of those unique experiences
— an NAEB party!
The discussion we held in the CPB office was highly
satisfactory from my point of view. I have some
over—the—weekend reflections.
Would you object to the National Educational Radio
Board of Directors meeting in conjunction with the
March 13-14 gathering of the CPB Radio Advisory Com¬
mittee? The board would meet on Friday afternoon and
Saturday morning following the CPB sessions.
The advantages to NER are obvious. Our budget does
not allow, at present, more than two meetings per year.
Since the board will be gathered for other business, it
would be most helpful if they might meet to take official
actions which otherwise would be delayed to May at our
next regularly scheduled meeting.
The Recorded Materials Distribution Center proposal is
most interesting. It has great promise and potential.
The key, in my thinking, is timing. Although educational
radio has considerable flexibility in the route it
takes to certain goals, I am concerned that the momentum
that is starting to build will not continue if radio
planning becomes too intertwined with television. I
support the joint effort concept but feel that our pro¬
posal to move NERN from Urbana to Washington, D. C. should
be pursued. This is a matter of urgency for radio and
a decision is needed — as Indicated in the proposal —
on or before March 31. To leave the move in limbo for
an extended period of time would be detrimental.
